snippet: The shift toward painkillers is forcing policy makers to re-examine the expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States.
abstract: America's drug problem is shifting from illicit substances like cocaine to abuse of prescription painkillers, forcing policy makers to re-examine the long and expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States; studies show that of the 36,450 overdose deaths in the country in 2008, 20,044 involved a prescription drug, more than all illicit drugs combined.

byline.original: By DAMIEN CAVE and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
byline.contributor: Damien Cave reported from Mexico City, and Michael S. Schmidt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The shift toward painkillers is forcing policy makers to re-examine the expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States.

headline.seo: U.S. Priority on Illegal Drugs Debated as Pill Abuse Rises
headline.main: Rise in Pill Abuse Forces New Look at U.S. Drug Fight
headline.print_headline: Rise in Pill Abuse Forces New Look at U.S. Drug Fight
